title: iPrivJoin: An ID-Private Data Join Framework for Privacy-Preserving Machine Learning
abstract: The world has observed an increasing trend in the development of Privacy-Preserving Machine Learning (PPML) for cross-silo collaborative model training over sensitive data. As the first essential step of cross-silo PPML, it is critical that the parties can align their dataset with privacy assurance, i.e., <italic>private data join</italic>. However, the existing private data join methods typically leak the ID information in the dataset intersection, which often raises privacy concerns. In this work, we propose <italic>iPrivJoin</italic>: a novel framework of ID-private data join for PPML. Compared with naively using circuit-based Private Set Intersection (circuit-PSI) for data join, the proposed framework has two advantages: 1) data volume reduction. <italic>iPrivJoin</italic> utilizes oblivious shuffle to securely trim off the redundant data that is outside the intersection, while the entire dataset needs to be carried to further process in the circuit-PSI based approach. 2) efficiency improvement. <italic>iPrivJoin</italic> introduces a new private encoding technique to avoid the expensive circuit evaluation that is needed in circuit-PSI. As a result, compared with directly using circuit-PSI, PPML with <italic>iPrivJoin</italic> enjoys approximately <inline-formula> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$3\times $ </tex-math></inline-formula> of speedup. Moreover, we propose a new oblivious shuffle protocol, which may be of independent interest. It achieves <inline-formula> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$1.44\times $ </tex-math></inline-formula> of speedup to the state-of-the-art in the real-world WAN network setting.
